issues.title: Schedule Viewer shows error for location_type = 2
issues.body:
When I try loading a GTFS feed in the Schedule Viewer shows these errors:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12948190/33946325-c7f8c070-e021-11e7-969d-22e1a33fd44f.png)

If I try validating it with the Feed Validator and the same errors are reported:

[validation-results.zip](https://github.com/google/transitfeed/files/1556023/validation-results.zip)

This seems to make a lot of stops not to appear in the map.

When I load it in other route planners (I use mainly the Open Trip Planner) it loads the entire transport network correctly with no errors.

issues.title: Adding Google Transit Extension: platform_code
issues.body:
Adding Google Transit Extension: platform_code

From reference
https://developers.google.com/transit/gtfs/reference/gtfs-extensions#station-platforms

**Field Name:** platform_code	

**Required:** Optional

**Details:**
Indicates the platform identifier for a platform stop. This should be just the platform identifier (eg. "G" or "3"). Words like “platform” or "track" (or the feed’s language-specific equivalent) should not be included. This allows feed consumers to more easily internationalize and localize the platform identifier into other languages.

Currently is showing:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1817333/25975058/c5d83848-3671-11e7-970f-03a5e3aeedd1.png)

Stops are not appearing in ScheduleViewer
issues.body:
I am not sure if this is a known issue. It has been awhile since I ran ScheduleViewer.  I am running a freshly installed 1.2.15 on Windows 10.   After loading a GTFS file that FeedValidator shows as perfectly (green) valid, I will see the map with a few of the stops throughout the system showing.  Which is normal behavior that I am use to from the older versions.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7353746/20456625/5c84dd44-ae48-11e6-893c-82b51ffc05b9.png)

However, when I bring up a line, It is not showing any stops.  It is recognizing the stops as it is counting the stops and on feeds that do not have a shapes.txt file, it is properly drawing the line.  

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7353746/20456683/270ccb26-ae49-11e6-96e0-8bb36aae0b81.png)

This is both with and without running ScheduleViewer as an administrator and this is happening both with and without a Google Maps API key.

issues.title: Summertime -> Wintertime
issues.body: Feedvalidator can't be run on the Saturday before going to wintertime.

issues.title: Time limit set at 999:59:59
issues.body: The time limit is set to 999:59:59, however, cannot see that this violates any definition of GTFS. Trying to implement GTFS into cargo transport and thus, time on a journey exceeds this limit regularly. Suggest to increase that limit to 2999:59:59 .

issues.title: Fix for truncating periods with undefined date range. Fixes #413
issues.body:
max(0, None) resulted in start_date being set to 0 (integer). This crashed at a later point
when trying to parse the date string 0 (int).
Now explicitly handling None when truncating.

issues.title: Crash when merging feeds consisting only of calendar_dates.txt (not calendar.txt)
issues.body:
The merge tool crashes with the following error:

`InvalidValue: Invalid value 0 in field start_date`

I have identified the root cause of this issue, and fixed this in my fork. Will submit a pull request shortly.

issues.title: Python 3 support.
issues.body: Would be great to have it.

issues.title: In pypy: Exception OperationalError (...) ignored
issues.body:
In pypy (2.5.1), I get the following on stderr

```
Exception OperationalError: OperationalError(u'unable to close due to unfinalized statements or unfinished backups',) in method __del__ of <transitfeed.schedule.Schedule object at 0x00000001076f6758> ignored
```

This seems to be related to cleaning up a Schedule object and possibly the use of weak references. It doesn't change the behavior of our programs as far as I can see, except that we get output on stderr. This will make our tool chain think that something broke, when it fact it didn't.

Note this issue in the pypy forum, where a sqlite library may have had a similar issue; https://bitbucket.org/pypy/pypy/issues/2006/operationalerror-when-there-are-a-lot-of. I don't quite get it.

issues.title: When trying to run kmlwriter.py, getting ImportError: No module named extensions.googletransit
issues.body:
Following error received when trying to run `kmlwriter.py`:
`ImportError: No module named extensions.googletransit`

Possible reasons: something is wrong with `pytz` in `requirements.txt`. When I ran `pip install requirements.txt`, I got following error: 

```
Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement requirements.txt (from versions: )
No matching distribution found for requirements.txt
```

I "manually" installed `pytz` by running `pip install pytz`, which seemed to work. Still, though, `kmlwriter.py` failed.

issues.title: No support for frequencies?
issues.body:
I've used Schedule Viewer to check on a GTFS feed that mostly uses frequencies rather than time tables and found that the viewer doesn't calculate stop times from frequency.txt file but shows stop times based on travel times instead.
Doesn't it support frequency schedules?

issues.title: Add support for translations.txt
issues.body:
Hello

The current version of the feed validator does not support the translations.txt file. This file is part of the extensions to GTFS, here:
https://support.google.com/transitpartners/answer/2450962

> In regions that have multiple official languages, transit agencies/operators typically have language-specific names and web pages.  In order to best serve riders in those regions, it is useful for the GTFS feed to include these language-dependent values.

Regards

issues.title: Profiling seems to cause an issue.
Fields in stop_times removed by merge tool
issues.body: Hi the merge tool seems to remove all the values from timepoints field, and all the 0 values from pickup_type and drop_off_type fields in stop_times.txt. Would you please consider delivering a patch so that those values can be retained? Many thanks.

issues.title: Doc: ScheduleViewer has some internal localhost binding config
issues.body:
https://github.com/google/transitfeed/wiki/ScheduleViewer

It would be nice if the documentation mentioned that, saving us from messing with every firewall level to find out it's the config.

P.S. I still don't know where ScheduleViewer binds to localhost preventing external requests from coming in.

issues.title: Does not validate all the required fields to be present on routes.txt
issues.body:
I noticed that feedvalidator does not validate that all the required fields are in place in input data? I would have expected that it reports 'Missing value for column column name (E7)' for all the missing fiels, which are specified to be required fields in GTFS reference (https://developers.google.com/transit/gtfs/reference).

As a testdata I used sample-feed.zip as a base (from here https://developers.google.com/transit/gtfs/examples/sample-feed.zip).
When running that against feedvalidator, I get just some warnings, which is ok.

I modified some lines of routes.txt to not have route_short_name or route_long_name (sample-feed-missing-routenames.zip) or route_id (sample-feed-no-routeid.zip). Oh, I cannot upload them here, well, this was what I did:

No route id:
route_id,agency_id,route_short_name,route_long_name,route_desc,route_type,route_url,route_color,route_text_color
,DTA,10,Airport - Bullfrog,,3,,,
-rest of file as in original-

No route_short/long_name
route_id,agency_id,route_short_name,route_long_name,route_desc,route_type,route_url,route_color,route_text_color
AB,DTA,,Airport - Bullfrog,,3,,,
BFC,DTA,20,,,3,,,
-rest of file as in original-

If you run feedvalidator against sample-feed-missing-routenames.zip, you get just the same warnings as with original zip-file. No errors from required missing route_short/long_name-fields. However, if you run validation against sample-feed-no-routeid.zip, it gives you a valid error as it should.

I would have expected it to notify errors on both zips, since required fields are missing.

ps. I was trying to see if I'm missing some command line argument or extension, but I think I'm using it correctly? Just like this -> feedvalidator.exe --limit_per_type=50  sample-feed-missing-routenames.zip

issues.title: Add "timepoint" in stops_times.txt to validator as official field
issues.body:
"Timepoint" field was added to GTFS in Feb 2, 2015 revision to GTFS spec (see [discussion](https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups#!topic/gtfs-changes/Ah-J9JP2rJY) and [spec](https://developers.google.com/transit/gtfs/reference#stop_timestxt-)).

Currently, the validator still flags "timepoint" as an unrecognized column:

> Unrecognized Column
> 
> Unrecognized column timepoint in file stop_times.txt. This might be a misspelled column name (capitalization matters!). Or it could be extra information (such as a proposed feed extension) that the validator doesn't know about yet. Extra information is fine; this warning is here to catch misspelled optional column names.
> in line 1 of stop_times.txt
> trip_id arrival_time    departure_time  stop_id stop_sequence   pickup_type drop_off_type   timepoint

issues.title: Error processing feed with unexpected newline character
issues.body:
Running feedvalidator.py on the [San Francisco Bay Ferries GTFS](http://data.trilliumtransit.com/gtfs/sfbay-ferries-ca-us/sfbay-ferries-ca-us.zip) currently returns the error:

Error: new-line character seen in unquoted field - do you need to open the file in universal-newline mode?

The calendar.txt file seems to be the culprit.

issues.title: route_short_name max length 6 characters?
issues.body:
Hello,

Validating data from the [MBTA](http://mbta.com/) which contains some `route_short_names` that caused the following error:

> Invalid value Shuttle in field route_short_name This route_short_name is relatively long, which probably means that it contains a place name. You should only use this field to hold a short code that riders use to identify a route. If this route doesn't have such a code, it's OK to leave this field empty.
> Invalid value 441/442 in field route_short_name This route_short_name is relatively long, which probably means that it contains a place name. You should only use this field to hold a short code that riders use to identify a route. If this route doesn't have such a code, it's OK to leave this field empty.
> Invalid value 214/216 in field route_short_name This route_short_name is relatively long, which probably means that it contains a place name. You should only use this field to hold a short code that riders use to identify a route. If this route doesn't have such a code, it's OK to leave this field empty.
> Invalid value 116/117 in field route_short_name This route_short_name is relatively long, which probably means that it contains a place name. You should only use this field to hold a short code that riders use to identify a route. If this route doesn't have such a code, it's OK to leave this field empty.

Since it doesn't seem like this is likely to be a configuration that is too out of the ordinary for transit agencies to use, I am wondering if the `route_short_name` needs to be so short. The gtfs spec itself doesn't specify a max length for this parameter.

Thanks,

-Raphael

issues.title: Lack of form closing tag in schedule_viewer, makes "find station" not working
issues.body:
_From [powc...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/110757038851057991288/) on January 12, 2013 11:01:31_

What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. run schedule_viewer with any gtfs file
2. put any name to "Find Station:" field and click search button. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The schedule_viewer is supposed to find station with that name, and display markers of that station. 
Nothing happens instead, and the web server logs the following lines:
localhost - - [12/Jan/2013 19:25:15] code 404, message Not Found
localhost - - [12/Jan/2013 19:25:15] "GET /json/savedata HTTP/1.1" 404 - What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? transitfeed-1.2.12, Windows XP, Firefox 18.0 Please provide any additional information below. The \gtfsscheduleviewer\files\index.html in line 720: <form onSubmit="saveData(); return false;"><input value="Save" type="submit"> lacks of </form> closing tag, making further inputs related to station search to be children of the saveData() form.
The issue is solved by adding </form> at the end of line 720 in index.html

issues.title: Memory Leak in transitfeed Python module
issues.body:
_From [liquidsu...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/103651021633430728253/) on November 30, 2012 09:48:57_

The following code results in a memory leak in the transitfeed library when processing multiple GTFS feeds (200+, but it's noticeable after just a few) in a loop.  A full script to exhibit the behavior is attached.

  for f in os.listdir("./gtfs/"):
    loader = transitfeed.Loader(feed_path="./gtfs/"+f, memory_db=False)
    schedule = loader.Load()    
    #del schedule
    #del loader

The following things have been attempted unsuccessfully to eliminate the leak:
1. Explicitly "del"-ing the objects (uncomment above code).
2. Creating the loader object with "memory_db=False"
3. Using the "map" function instead of a loop.

Since a schedule object creates a sqlite3 database and connection (in memory or a tempfile), my guess is that the connection is not being closed properly.  However, the __del__ method for Schedule does seem to attempt to do this... What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? - I have tested this with transitfeed 1.2.12 (both from SVN and PIP).
- I am using Ubuntu 12.10 64-bit with Python 2.7.3 and libsqlite3 3.7.13.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/googletransitdatafeed/issues/detail?id=354_

issues.title: Refactor transitfeed to improve readability
issues.body:
_From [fabien.v...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/103527819951360492630/) on April 07, 2011 07:46:58_

This Issue is a placeholder for all refactoring ideas that would make transitfeed better.

1) Unify the ValidateXYZ() functions: some return true when what they're looking at is valid, some return false.
I propose to rename them all to XYZIsValid() and make them return true if what they test is valid.

2) in util.py, the Validate() function have some special logic to "accept" empty fields, and then run no validation. This is not the most readable solution, and it hurts the extension -- it would be much better to make the transit entity's main Validate() function call the sub-ValidateXYZ() function only if the necessary fields are present.

issues.title: Feedvalidator is (overly) fussy about number format
issues.body:
_From [drinc...@google.com](https://code.google.com/u/108717965101138162194/) on April 05, 2011 05:31:45_

What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Include a number value that is a float without a leading zero. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I would expect it to just deal with it.
Instead, it logs InvalidFloatValue warnings.

The code in FloatStringToFloat (util.py) checks that floats match a regex, but even if they don't match, it converts them anyway.

The reason for the regex match is not included in the code and so I propose that it is simplified to just:

try:
  parsed_value = float(float_string)
except ValueError:
  problems.InvalidFloatValue(float_string)

That is, it's an invalid float if it doesn't convert to a float. :-) What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? 1.2.6 on Linux Please provide any additional information below.

_From [derek.ho...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/104831808664641130522/) on August 20, 2010 15:32:43_

When a trip ends after midnight, the schedule viewer displays the time as, for example, "25:00" meaning 1:00am. Please display the time as it would appear on a schedule[1], instead of "hours since midnight of the first day of the trip".

[1] A schedule in the local time zone (use the proposed stop_timezone field when available).

When a trip spans at least one midnight, also please specify for each stop which day of the trip the time refers to.

issues.title: Move some classes and functions from test/test*py to test/util.py
issues.body:
_From [a...@google.com](https://code.google.com/u/102593797636503890639/) on August 05, 2010 09:26:40_

We now have an extensibility mechanism, and each extension should have unit tests. There are some functions in classes in test/test*py files that might be useful for the extensions' tests as well, and as such they should be moved to test/util.py.

Examples of this are the classes MemoryZipTestCase and ValidationTestCase that currently live in testtransitfeed.py.

All base classes and util functions should be reviewed and moved to test/util.py if it makes sense.

issues.title: Memory Error Crashes 1.2.5 Windows EXE and 1.2.5 PY - Our Combined Feed seems to be too large.
issues.body:
_From [rollin.h...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/104312837823889426043/) on June 18, 2010 12:40:12_

What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Run our combined datafeed against newer versions of FeedValidator 2. Newer being the last several versions, inclusing the python application. 3. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? A validation HTML page with errors and warnings.
We see nothing instead, not, in general, even a transitfeedcrash file.
(although by using the 1.2.5 py instead of the 1.2.5 win exe, I got it to
produce a transitfeedcrash file.) What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? I've tried the following builds:

1.2.5 Win exe, 1.2.5 py, 1.1.9 win, 1.2.0 win, 1.2.1 win, 1.2.2 win, 1.2.3 win

Dell t7400 Xeon 3GHz, Win XP Pro SP3, 4GB Ram Please provide any additional information below. Pls see attached transitfeedcrash.txt

When a copy of the transit feed was sent to Google, they COULD run a validation (and it ran with no errors, but a large number of warnings,
mostly too fast travels and route short name warnings) (See attached as well)

When I randomly removed 25% of all stop_times.txt records, the feed would validate without errors (albeit with warnings).  This makes me pretty sure thats its a size issue.  

We have two shakeups a year, and when they occur, I need to send combined feeds to Google.  Often I've been able to work around the size issue (by using an earlier version of the validator), but this time nothing worked.

Thanks for looking at the Issue:

issues.title: Reduce and/or refactor internal transitfeed dependencies
issues.body:
_From [a...@google.com](https://code.google.com/u/102593797636503890639/) on June 15, 2010 09:50:59_

We need to map the internal dependencies of the transitfeed package and try to reduce them. It's easy to introduce circular imports, which is a pretty good sign that things can probably be improved.

If reducing the number of dependencies is not possible we should at the very least check what can be refactored in the transitfeed package to stop the circular imports from happening so easily.

issues.title: No warning on missing DST adjustment
issues.body:
_From [nova...@novalis.org](https://code.google.com/u/100495712148588182770/) on March 18, 2010 15:53:10_

GTFS usually requires an adjusted schedule on daylight savings time
switchover days, due to the change in the definition of arrival and
departure times.  When this is missing, the feed validator ought to give a
warning.

issues.title: transfers.txt support of stations
issues.body:
_From [tom.brow...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/102106286505569161652/) on February 22, 2010 09:41:53_

According to the spec from_stop_id and to_stop_id get this handling "If the 
stop ID refers to a station that contains multiple stops, this transfer rule 
applies to all stops in that station."
This should be accounted for when validating. In particular checks for 
duplicate transfers ( issue 140 ) should catch things like

from_stop,to_stop,transfer_type
stop_a,parent_of_a_and_b,0
parent_of_a_and_b,stop_b,3

issues.title: Feature request: Detect ultra slow trip legs in feedvalidator
issues.body:
_From [vi...@google.com](https://code.google.com/u/106482988238218739768/) on January 05, 2010 04:58:57_

Some experimental GTFS feeds have bad times that jump 24h with no reason.
A simple way to detect them is to introduce a warning, that could be an 
error when the confidence is high, about ultra slow trip legs:
when two consecutive timed entries in stop_times.txt of the same trip have a 
time difference >= 24h and their geodesic distance is <= 100km, this is very 
likely to be an error.

Note that 'two consecutive timed entries' means that there could be untimed 
entries in between.

issues.body:
_From [tom.brow...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/102106286505569161652/) on December 10, 2009 14:45:43_

I've seen a few feeds with a fairly complex fare scheme and a fatal problem:
There is a fare_id with price=0 and no fare_rules. This fare will work for 
any trip and because it is cheaper than all other fare options will be used 
for all trips. It makes all trips of an agency free.

issues.title: Feature request: Check whether a route have reverse direction
issues.body:
_From [wLiu.s...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/113586349212745399416/) on September 22, 2009 01:34:33_

What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Usually a route has two directions(A->B and B-A), but there are also some
exceptional cases, like a route only has one direction, or a route's
reverse direction doesn't have the same start/end stations (one direction:
A->B, the other B->A->A0), or a route has more than 2 directions. 

The real case is China (or some other countries) is that almost all routes
have two reverse directions(A->B and B->A). So this check will be disabled
by default and be turned on by flag like --reverse_directions_check=true.

issues.title: Feature Request: merge two files for the same service period
issues.body:
_From [devin.br...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/101935729464922701035/) on March 17, 2009 13:29:50_

Feature Request
The merge tool allows users to merge two files with disjoint service 
periods.  I request to also allow the merge tool to merge two files with 
the same service periods.

Reasoning
For larger systems, many different services must be merged together (bus, 
light rail, commuter rail) or different systems for a large metropolitan 
organization (i.e. many small city systems).  Sometimes, these systems have 
different effective dates on schedules, requiring an update of only one 
part of the feed.  Creating the feeds separately and joining them together 
would aid in creating the combined feed, especially when one service 
changes and others don't.

issues.title: warn when trips per day or week changes a lot
issues.body:
_From [tom.brow...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/102106286505569161652/) on July 30, 2008 07:10:27_

a few people have complained that they don't get a warning about feed
expiration when a single service_id is ending soon but other service_ids
continue. We can't add a warning when any single service_id expires because
some feeds, for example merged feeds and those that cross a schedule
change, have a legitimate need for ending service_ids. Instead we should
warn if there is a big change in trips per day or week within the upcoming
weeks. A graph of this in the validation html would be nice too. https://code.google.com/apis/chart/ makes it easy.

issues.title: possible to output route without agency_id
issues.body:
_From [tom.brow...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/102106286505569161652/) on March 19, 2008 18:06:24_

According to the spec, if routes.txt includes an agency_id column all rows
must have a value. Ideally Route.GetFieldValuesTuple would use the
schedule's default route if self.route_id is None and there would be a way
to totally omit the column if only one agency is in the schedule.
The easiest fix is to make agency_id required when creating a Route object
and populate it with the default agency in the loader when loading
routes.txt. I don't like adding things so that transitfeed loading and
writing a feed modifies its content.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/googletransitdatafeed/issues/detail?id=47_

In pull #383 we changed the behavior of kmlparser.py to use the <Placemark> <name/> element as the shape_id when generatings shapes from LineString features.  However, that broke a test for kmlwriter.py where the output of kmlwriter.py is fed immediately into kmlparsery.py.  The issue is that kmlwriter.py also outputs stop-pattern LineStrings for each route, where the name associated with each feature is not necessarily unique across different routes.  When importing these features, we get duplicate shape_id errors on import as result.  The previous code avoided this problem because it just generated a unique shape_id for each shape.

My fix tries to maintain the best of both worlds.  We first try to import a shape with the element name as the shape_id.  If there is no existing shape with that id or if the existing shape has the same set of points, we are ok.  However, if there is a duplicate shape with different points, we modify the shape_id of the new shape to avoid conflicts.

googletransit extension of transitfeed.Agency (includes the BCP-47 language code validation).

This change is deprecating field 'agency_ticket_url' in favor of the new field 'agency_fare_url' (https://sites.google.com/site/gtfschanges/spec-changes-summary#agency) and it is deprecating the fields 'agency_lang' and 'agency_timezone' in agency in favor of the fields 'feed_lang' and 'feed_timezone' in feed_info. The agency extension is the first extension which uses the new _DEPRECATED_FIELD_NAMES functionality. So this revision includes some modifications for not having to change all the old unit tests which use one of the deprecated fields. This was done by adding the 'DeprecatedColumn' exception to the ignore_types list of the problem accumulator of most tests. This revision also adds a new command line argument --error_types_ignore_list which allows adding to the ignore_types list e.g. in the integration tests.

This change is adding pybcp47 module for supporting BCP-47 language code validation of the 'agency_lang' and 'feed_lang' fields. The language code parsing is implemented as a separate pybcp47 module for being able to move it later to a separate project if required. It also comes with its own unit tests. These tests can run standalone and they are being invoked from within the testgoogletransitextension.py file for being included in
the nosetests run.

Review at http://codereview.appspot.com/4271073/

googletransit extension of transitfeed.Route and transitfeed.Stop (routes.txt and stops.txt)

This change adds extensions.googletransit.Route which extends transitfeed.Route in order to add HVT (Hierarchical Vehicle Type) route types as proposed in https://sites.google.com/site/gtfschanges/spec-changes-summary#routes and in order to make the field 'co2_per_km' known and validated as proposed https://sites.google.com/site/gtfschanges/open-proposals

The new extensions.googletransit.Stop extends transitfeed.Stop in order to make the fields 'stop_timezone', 'vehicle_type' and 'wheelchair_boarding' known and validated as proposed in https://sites.google.com/site/gtfschanges/spec-changes-summary#stops and in order to add and validate the location_type 2 (entrance).

This revision contains the first extension of the FeedValidator.

It contains the general 'skeleton' for extensions and the initial extension
module specific to Google Transit.

The folder structure for the extension currently is python/extensions/.
This extensions folder is an empty python module. Each extension in a
subfolder like googletransit/ must be a valid python module as well.
For more information about the extension structure check the README
in python/extensions/ or the wiki at
http://code.google.com/p/googletransitdatafeed/wiki/FeedValidatorExtensions

This revision contains the googletransit extension. It overrides the
transitfeed.FareAttribute and transitfeed.Schedule classes for adding
new fields and for adding and changing validation code. It creates a
new class FeedInfo for validating the Google Transit specific feed_info.txt.

List of changes of the googletransit extension to the default behavior:
* extensions.googletransit.FareAttribute:
  - extension of transitfeed.FareAttribute
  - adds new field 'agency_id' and function ValidateAgencyId()
* extensions.googletransit.FeedInfo:
  - new class for validating feedinfo.txt
  - validates fields 'feed_publisher_name', 'feed_publisher_url', 'feed_lang',
    'feed_timezone', 'feed_valid_from' and 'feed_valid_until'
  - recognizes field 'feed_version'
  - The valid dates range specified by 'feed_valid_from' and 'feed_valid_until'
    is only used to check the feed validity. It's not used for other purposes.
    In particular, services and service exceptions are not dropped or reduced if
    they are defined outside this valid dates range.
* extensions.googletransit.Schedule:
  - extension of transitfeed.Schedule
  - new feed_info variable and AddFeedInfoObject() method in order to be able to
    register a extensions.googletransit.FeedInfo object in the Schedule
  - validates FeedInfo.feed_lang against Agency.agency_lang
  - validates FeedInfo.feed_timezone against Agency.agency_timezone
  - checks that all Agencies have the same timezone
  - overrides ValidateFeedStartAndExpirationDates() in order to take
    FeedInfo.feed_valid_from and FeedInfo.feed_valid_until into account

Starting the FeedValidator with this extension is done with the command
./feedvalidator.py <feed_filename> --extension extensions.googletransit

Fix handling of empty string stop_lat and stop_lon values in Stop.

Stop.stop_lat and Stop.stop_lon can be passed into Stop either as string or as float value. If being a string they get converted into floats during execution of Stop.ValidateStopLatitude and Stop.ValidateStopLongitude. These two functions initially do check if stop_lat and stop_lon are not empty (e.g. "if self.stop_lat:"). Empty strings ( in double quotes "") do evaluate as False and thus do not get touched by these functions. Thus empty strings remain strings which leads to errors e.g. in Stop.ValidateStopNotTooCloseToOrigin which assumes to get float values to be validated.

This change adds a "setattr(self, required, None)" to Stop.ValidateStopRequiredFields. Thus an empty string gets explicitly set to None. The checks in Stop.ValidateStopLatitude and Stop.ValidateStopLongitude are now more specific testing explicitly for None (e.g. "if self.stop_lat is not None:").

This fix comes from http://code.google.com/p/googletransitdatafeed/issues/detail?id=258

Adds detection of large transfers.

- If the transfer is between two stops that are too far away issue a warning (if
>2km) or an error (if >10km).

at 2m/s (very fast walking) issue a warning. An intended side effect is that
stops that are too close together (< 240m) never trigger this.

GetTimeInterpolatedStops uses polyline connecting stops instead of
straight-line between timepoints.

William says:
  Right now, GetTimeInterpolatedStops measures the time of a non-timepoint
  stop based on its relative distance between the two timepoints. This
  mostly works fine, but there are cases where a stop in the sequence might
  be geographically further from the next timepoint than its predecessor,
  resulting in some stops having earlier stop times than their predecessors
  (i.e. going backwards in time). A better strategy is to sum up the total
  distance travelled between timepoints and calculate the time based on the
  percentage of the distance travelled at each given point.

  As requested on the CodeReview page, I explicitly release this change under
  the Apache 2.0 license.

Review at http://codereview.appspot.com/8710

This change enables the shape importer to handle shapefiles
where there are separate polylines between every station on every line.

Some trips on some lines may skip stops if they are express trips.  So sometimes
we have to piece together several polylines to get from one station to the next
in a trip.  So to do all this, I implemented a version of the A* algorithm to
search for the shortest path between two stations, traveling over the graph of
all the polylines in the shape file.

Another wrinkle is that input shapefiles may not always be complete.  In order
to provide a way to manually patch things up, I added a flag to shape_importer
to allow passing in an extra shapes.txt file (in GTFS format) to augment the
polylines in the shapefile.

Along the way I added some debugging messages and a --verbosity flag to control
their output.

gtfsscheduleviewer/files/index.html, adding lat/long to the pop-up bubble for
stations in the schedule viewer.  (Useful for debugging.)

pull_requests.title: Adding Google Transit Extension: platform_code
pull_requests.body:
Adding Google Transit Extension: platform_code

From reference
https://developers.google.com/transit/gtfs/reference/gtfs-extensions#station-platforms

**Field Name:** platform_code	

**Required:** Optional

**Details:**
Indicates the platform identifier for a platform stop. This should be just the platform identifier (eg. "G" or "3"). Words like “platform” or "track" (or the feed’s language-specific equivalent) should not be included. This allows feed consumers to more easily internationalize and localize the platform identifier into other languages.

Currently is showing:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1817333/25975058/c5d83848-3671-11e7-970f-03a5e3aeedd1.png)

_From [a...@google.com](https://code.google.com/u/102593797636503890639/) on December 02, 2009 13:25:24_

A quick workaround was committed as r1223 . As I mentioned in the code review:

It was the simplest fix I could think of, though it is probably not the best - the height is fixed instead of being dynamic and using only 
the required space.

The fixed value was chosen with 800x600 resolutions in mind. At this resolution the text above the graph occupies four lines instead of 
two, and that has to be accounted for. This leaves a blank space below the graph at bigger resolutions, and bigger font sizes are not 
properly supported (because the height is fixed).

That said, and given the purpose of this tool, I do think that having this fix is better than leaving the schedule viewer as it is. If someone 
more knowledgeable of web development knows how to fix it properly or if there's time in the future then this can be revisited then.

_From [tom.brow...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/102106286505569161652/) on November 05, 2008 12:33:18_

The current release gives the distance between stops and only warns about stops
within 2m of each other.

I think it is nice to have only one stop_id per place that passengers think of a
stop, independent of if they are waiting for service from the same or different agencies.

Imagine a tool on a phone (or get http://headwayblog.com/wiki/index.php?title=Tranzit ) that looks at your current
location, lets you pick a nearby stop and then shows next departure times. Often
several routes stop at the same location and go roughly the same direction. In this
case it probably makes more sense to list all these routes at the same stop instead
of making the user pick "SE Corner of Masonic/#71" then go back and pick "SE Corner
of Masonic/#6". The nextbus signs at stops like this typically scroll through the
departures of each route.

While making it easy to publish data is very important, making it easy to produce
meaningful applications using the data with minimal processing and heuristics is also
important. Perhaps this should be a thread on gtfs-changes regarding stop merging.

Is it a short version of this argument that you want in the validator output?

_From [arnoegw.code@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/arnoegw.code@gmail.com/) on November 11, 2009 09:37:17_

The current public GTFS spec (dated March 30, 2009) already says:

The color difference between route_color and route_text_color should provide
sufficient contrast when viewed on a black and white screen. http://www.w3.org/TR/AERT#color-contrast offers a useful algorithm for evaluating
color contrast.

I will switch the luminance computation in the transitfeed code to the formula from
that doc but leave the threshold for a warning lower than their recommendation
(similar to where it was before), because they talk about running, normal-size text,
which has higher demands than line names that are not read at a longer stretch and
are probably shown in bigger font.

While doing this, I noticed that the spec's W3C reference is outdated.  (In fact,
it's a 9 year old draft(!).)  The current thing seems to be this: http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#visual-audio-contrast-contrast Its
formula is more involved, and we should first discuss what we want in the spec before
writing code for it.
